Key Match Events: Mookie Betts and Will Smith each homered in the first three innings
Will Smith's seven postseason homers the most by a catcher in franchise history
Seven different players had reached base by the third inning
Ryan Brasier started the game, pitched 1 ⅓ innings, and seven others followed, yielding just seven hits
Mookie Betts hit a first-inning home run for the second night in a row
Gavin Lux hit a two-run homer in the second inning
Will Smith hit a two-run homer in the third inning
Tommy Edman executed a rare safety squeeze in the seventh inning to score Max Muncy
Pre-Game Insights: The Dodgers were without their starting first baseman before the first pitch
They were without their starting shortstop and had three reserves in the lineup
They were on the brink of yet another disappointing postseason exit
Dodgers manager Dave Roberts emphasized the importance of strong bullpen performance
All-Star first baseman Freddie Freeman was scratched an hour before the game started with his sore right ankle
Shortstop Miguel Rojas was still hobbled after leaving Game 3
The re-organized lineup still produced and by the time they play Friday night, should look different with Freeman back in the squad and $325 million starter Yoshinobu Yamamoto on the mound
Post-Match Reflections: They’re ready for Game 5, but with this series so compelling, you can’t blame anyone for wishing it was a best-of-seven
Just one more game, one more victory, and they’ll be back in the NLCS, eight victories away from winning their first World Series title in a full season since 1988
Miscellaneous Highlights: Weather or field conditions affecting the match (e.g., 'Rain delays led to the game being postponed until the next day')
The game went into 15 innings before a decisive home run by Mike Trout
